Expectation1: Teaching children moral values and discipline
Situation1: The child is caught stealing snacks at a store, and the parent needs to handle the situation
Expectation2: Deliver packages on time and to the correct address
Situation2: A package arrives slightly later than expected, but still within the same day
Story: I was just finishing my last delivery of the afternoon, glancing at the clock on my phone, when I got a call from the store manager. My heart sank as I heard my son’s name—he’d been caught slipping a candy bar into his pocket. As a parent, I knew I had to teach him right from wrong, to show him that stealing is never acceptable, no matter how small the item. But as a delivery person, I was already running behind. The next package was supposed to be at the customer’s door by five, and I was cutting it close. If I stopped to handle this with my son, I’d be late, risking a complaint or even my job. If I ignored the call, I’d be failing him as a parent, missing a crucial moment to guide him. The weight of both roles pressed on me, each demanding my full attention, each with consequences I couldn’t ignore. I stood there, keys in hand, torn between the two worlds that needed me right now.
